unnormalised: **Environmental News: Innovative Waste Management Strategies Emerge in Mumbai**
normalised: **Environmental News: Innovative Waste Management Strategies Emerge in Mumbai**

unnormalised: Mumbai, India - October 26, 2023 - The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) is implementing novel strategies to tackle the city's growing waste management challenges. Citing inspiration from the cleanliness portrayed in the Bollywood film "Swades," officials aim to foster greater community participation.
normalised: Mumbai, India - October twenty sixth, two thousand and twenty three - The B M C is implementing novel strategies to tackle the city's growing waste management challenges. Citing inspiration from the cleanliness portrayed in the Bollywood film "Swades," officials aim to foster greater community participation.

unnormalised: The BMC is partnering with the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Bombay to explore advanced waste segregation technologies, potentially reducing landfill burden by up to 30%. Pilot projects are underway in Bandra-Kurla Complex (BKC), focusing on composting organic waste and recycling plastic.
normalised: The B M C is partnering with the Indian Institute of Technology (I I T) Bombay to explore advanced waste segregation technologies, potentially reducing landfill burden by up to thirty percent. Pilot projects are underway in Bandra-Kurla Complex (B K C), focusing on composting organic waste and recycling plastic.

unnormalised: "Our goal is a cleaner, greener Mumbai," stated BMC Commissioner, I.S. Chahal, at a recent press conference. The BMC has allocated Rs. 200 crore towards infrastructure development, including modern waste processing plants and improved transportation systems. 50 new garbage compactors are expected on the roads within the next month, covering approximately 150 km of routes. This initiative intends to significantly reduce roadside litter and improve air quality in the city.
normalised: "Our goal is a cleaner, greener Mumbai," stated B M C Commissioner, I. S. Chahal, at a recent press conference. The B M C has allocated rupee two hundred crore towards infrastructure development, including modern waste processing plants and improved transportation systems. fifty new garbage compactors are expected on the roads within the next month, covering approximately one hundred and fifty kilometer of routes. This initiative intends to significantly reduce roadside litter and improve air quality in the city.
